titleStmt.title: The Dutch courtezan. As it vvas playd in the Blacke-Friars, by the Children of her Maiesties Reuels. VVritten by Iohn Marston.
titleStmt.author: Marston, John, 1575?-1634.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by T[homas] P[urfoot] for Iohn Hodgets, and are to be sould at his shop in Paules Church-yard,

note.p: Reproduction of the original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

div.p: AS IT WAS PLAYD IN THE Blacke-Friars, by the Children of her Maiesties Reuels.
AT LONDON, Â¶ Printed by T. P. for Iohn Hodgets, and are to be sould at his shop in Paules Church-yard. 1605.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: SLight hastie labours in this easie Play,
Present not what you would, but what we may:
For this vouchsafe to know the onely end
Of our now studie is, not to offend.
Yet thinke not, but like others raile we could,
(Best art Presents, not what it can, but should)
And if our pen in this seeme ouer slight,
We striue not to instruct, but to delight,
As for some few, we know of purpose here
to taxe, and scowt: know firme art cannot feare
Vaine rage: onely the highest grace we pray
Is, you'le not taxe, vntill you iudge our Play.
Thinke and then speake: tis rashnesse, and not wit
To speake what is in passion, and not iudgement fit:
Sit then, with faire exspectance, and suruay
Nothing but passionate man in his slight play,
Who hath this onely ill: to some deem'd worst,
A modest diffidence, and selfe mistrust.

div.head: Fabulae argumentum.
div.p: THe difference betwixt the loue of a Curtezan, & a wife, is the full scope of the Play, which intermixed with the deceits of a wittie Citie Iester, fils vp the Comedie.

list.item: Cocledemoy A knauishly witty City companion.

div.head: THE Dutch Curtezan. Turpe est difficiles habere nugas
Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter 3: Pages with lightes, Malligrubb, Freeuile, Malhoureus, Tisifen. & Caqueteur.

sp.speaker: Freeuile.
sp.p: NAy comfort my good hoast Sharke, my good, Mulligrubb.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Aduance thy snout, doe not suffer thy sorrowful nose to droppe on thy spanish leather ierkin, most hardly honest Mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What, cogging Cocledemoy is runne away with a neast of goblets, true, what then? they will be hammerd out well enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Sure, some wise man would finde them out presently.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes sure, if we could finde out some wise man presently.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How was the plate lost? how did it vanish?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: In most sincere prose thus: that man of much money, some witte, but lesse honestie, cogging Cocledemoy, comes this night late into mine hostes Mulligrubs Tauerne heere, cals for a roome, the house being ful, Cocledemoy consorted with his moueable chattle, his instrument of fornication, the bawdy Mrs.

sp.speaker: Mary Faugh,
sp.p:
are imparlarde next the streete good poultrie was
their foode, black bird, Larke, woodcocke, and mine hoast here, comes in, cryes God blesse you, and departes: A blinde Harper enters, craues audience, vncaseth, playes, the Drawer for female priuatnes sake is nodded out, who knowing that whosoeuer will hit the mark of profit, must like those that shoot in stone-bowes winke with one eye, growes blind a the right side and departs.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: He shal answere for that winking with one eye at the last day.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Let him haue day till then, and he will winke with both his eyes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Cocledemoy perceiuing none in the roome but the blind Harper, (whose eyes heauen had shut vp, from beholding wickednesse,) vnclaspes a casement to the street very patiently, pockets vp 5. bowles vnnaturally, thrustes his wench forth the window, and him selfe most preposterously with his heeles forward followes, the vnseeing Harper playes on, bids the empty dishes and the treacherous candles much good do them. The Drawer returnes, but out alas, not onely the, but also the beast of goblets were flowne away, Laments are raisde.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Which did not pierce the heauens.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Drawers mone, mine hoast doth crie, the bowles are gone.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Hic finis Priami.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay, be not iaw falne, my most sharking Mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Tis your iust affliction remember the sinnes of the fellar, and repent, repent.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I am not iawfalne, but I will hang the contracting Cocledemoy, and theres an end of't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.p: Is it a right stone, it shewes well by candlelight.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So doe many thinges that are counterfeite, but I assure you this is a right Diamond.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.p: Might I borrow it of you, it will not a little graue my finger in visitation of my Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why vse it most sweet Cuqueture, vse it.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.p: Thankes good Sir, ti's growne high night: Gentles, rest to you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: A torch, found wench, soft sleepe, and sanguine dreames to you both on boy.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let me bid you good rest.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Not so trust me, I must bring my friend home: I dare not giue you vp to your owne companie, I feare the warmth of wine and youth, will draw you to some Common house of lasciuious entertainement.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Most necessarie buildings Malheureus euer since my intention of Marriage, I doe pray for their continuance.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Lou'd Sir, your reason?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Marry least my house should be made one: I would haue married men loue the Stewes, as Englishmen lou'd the low Countreys: wish war should be maintain'd there, least it should come home to their owne dores: what, suffer a man to haue a hole to put his head in, though hee goe to the Pillorie for it: Youth and Appetite are aboue the Clubbe of Hercules.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This lust is a most deadly sinne sure.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, tis a most liuely sinne sure.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Well I am sure, tis one of the head sinnes.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Nay, I am sure it is one of the middle sinnes.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Pitie, tis growne a most dayly vice.

sp.speaker: Free
sp.l: But a more nightly vice ,I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.p: Well, tis a sinne.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I, or else few men would wish to go to Heauen :& not to disguise with my friend, I am now giving the way of all flesh.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Not to a Curtezan.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A courteous one.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: What to a Sinner?

sp.speaker: Free
sp.p: A reale Publican.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: Deere my lo'ud friend, let me be free with you,
Know Sir, the strongest argument that speakes
Against the soules eternitie is lust.
The Wisemans folly, and the fools wisdom
But to grow wild in loose lasciuiousnesse,
Given up to heat, and sensuall Appetite:
Nay to expose your health and strength and name,
Your precious time, and with that time the hope
Of due preferment aduantageous meanes,
Of any worthy end to the stale vse,
The common bosome Of a money Creature,
One that sells human flesh ,Mangonist,

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p:
Alas good creatures, what would you haue them doe?
would you haue them get their liuing by the curse of man, the sweat of their browes? so they doe, euerie man must follow his trade, and euerie woman her occupation: a poore decayed mechanicall mans wife, her husband is layd vp, may not she lawfully be layd downe, when her husbands onely rising, is by his wifes falling? a Captaines wife wants meanes, her Commaunder lyes in open field abroad, may not she lye in ciuile armes at home. A waighting Gentlewoman that had wont to take say to her Lady, miscaries, or so: the Court misfortune throwes her downe, may not the Citie curtesie take her vp: doe you know no Alderman would pitie such a womans case: why is charity growne a finne? or releeuing the poore and impotent an offence? You will say beasts take no money for their fleshly entertainment: true, because they are beasts, therefore beastly, onely men giue to loose, because they are men, therefore manly: and indeede, wherein should they bestow their money better? In Land, the title may be crackt: In Houses, they may bee burnt: In apparell, will weare: In wine, alas for pitie our throate is but short: But employ your money vpon women, and a thousand to nothing, some one of them will bestow that on you, which shall sticke by you as long as you liue; they are no ingratefull persons, they with giue quite for quo: do ye protest, they'le sweate, doe you they theyle fall doe you fall, they'le rise, do you giue them, the french Crowne, they'le giue you the french; O iustus iusta, iustum They sell their bodies: doe not better persons sell their soules? nay, since all things haue been sould, honor, iustice, aim: my, euen God himselfe, Aye me, what base ignoblenesse is it to sell the pleasure of a wanton bed.
Why doe men scrape, why heape to full heapes ioyne.
But for his Mistresse, who would care for coyne,
For this I hold to be deny'd of no man,
All thinges are made for man, and man for woman, giue me my fee.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Of ill you merite well: my hearts good friend, Leaue yet at length, at length, for know this euer Tis no such sinne to erre, but to perseuer.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p:
Beautie is womans vertue, loue the lifes Musique: and woman the daintines or second course of heauens curious workmanship, since then beauty loue and woman are good, how can
the loue of womans beawty be bad and, Bonum quo communius to melius; wil't then goe with me?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Whether?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: To a house of saluation.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Saluation?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Yes 'twill make thee repent. wil't goe to the family of loue? I will shew thee my creature: a pretty nimble eye Dutch Tanakin; An honest soft harted impropriation, a soft plumpe, round cheekt froe, that has beauty inough, for her vertue, vertue enough for a woman, and woman enough for any reasonable man in my knowledge: wil't passe along with me?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: What to a Brothell, to behold an impudent prostitution, fye on't shall hate the whole sex to see her: the most odious spectacle the earth can present, is an modest vulger woman.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Good still: my braine shall keep't: you must goe as you loue me.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Well: Ile go to make her loath the shame shee's in, The sight of vice augments the hate of sinne

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: The sight of vice augments the hate of sinne, very fine perdy.

div.head: Scena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Coclo:
sp.p: Mary, Mary Faugh.

sp.speaker: Marc
sp.p: Hem.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Come my worshipfull Rotten Rough bellide Baud, ha my blew tooth'd Patrones of naturall wickednesse, giue me the gobletts.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: By yea, and by nay, maister Cocledemoy I feare you're play the knaue and restore them.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: No by the Lord Aunt, Restitution is Catholique and thou know'st we loue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Oracles are seas'd: Tempus preteritum, do'st heare my worshipful glisterpipe, thou vngodly fyer that burnt Dianas Temple, do'st heare Baud,

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p:
In very good truthnes you are the foulest mouth'd prophaine railing Brother, call a woman the most vngodly names: I must confesse we all eate of the forbidden fruite, and for mine
owne part tho I am one of the family of loue and as they say a bawd that couers the multitude of sinnes, yet I trust I am none of the wicked that eate fish a Fridaies.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Hang toastes, I raile at thee my worshipfull organ bellowes that fills the pipes, my fine ratling fleamy cough a the lunges and cold with a Pox, I raile at thee what my right pretious pandres supportres of Barbar Surgeons and inhauntres of lotium and dyet drinke: I raile at thee necessary damnation, Ile make an oration, I, in praise of thy most courtly in fashion, and most pleasureable function. I.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: I prethee do, I loue to heare my selfe prais'd, as well as any old Ladie, I.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: List then, a Band, first for her profession or vocation it it is most worshipfull of all the 12. Companies, for as that trade it most honorable that sells the best comoÌdityes, as the Draper is more worshipfull then the poyntmaker, the silkeman more worshipfull then the Draper, and the Goldsmith more honorable then both, Little Mary: so, that Baud aboue all, her shop has the best ware, for where these fell but cloath sattens, and iewels, shee sels diuine vertues as virginitie, modestie and such rare Iemmes, and those not like a petty chapman, by retaile, but like a great marchant by whole sale, wa, ha, ho, and who are her customers, not base corn cutters, or sowgelders, but most rare wealthie Knightes, and most rare bountifull Lordes are her customers Againe, where as no trade or vocation profiteth, but by the losse and displeasure of another, as the Marchant thriues non but by the licentiousnes of giddie, and vnsetled youth: the Lawyer, but by (the vexation of his client, the Phisition, but by the maladies of his patient, onely my smothe gumbde Bawd hues by others pleasure, and onely growes rich by other rising. O mercifull gaine, O righteous in-come. So much for her vocation, trade and life, as for their death, how can it bee bad, since their wickednesse is alwayes before their eyes, and a deathes head most commonly on their middle finger. To conclude, ti's most certaine they must needes both liue well, and doe well, since most commonly they liue in Clearken-well, and dye in Bridewell Dixi Mary.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come along, yonders the preface or exordium to my wench, the bawde: Fetch, fetch. What M. Cocledemoy, is your knaueshippe yet stirring, looke to it, Mulligrub lyes for you.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: The more foole he, I can lye for my selfe, worshipfull friend, hang toastes, I vannish. Ha my fine boy thou art a scholler, and hast read Tullies Offices, my fine knaue, hang toastes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Vintner will toast you and he catch you.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: I will draw the Vintner to the stoope, and when he runs low tilt him, he my fine knaue, art going to thy recreation.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes my capticeous raskall.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Thou wilt looke like a foole then by and by.

sp.speaker: Free
sp.p: Looke like a foole why?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Why according to the old saying, A begger when he is lowsing of himselfe lookes like a Philosopher, a hard bound Philosopher, when he is on the stoole, lookes like a tyrant, and a wise man, when hee is in his belly act, lookes like a foole, God give your worship good rest, grace and mercy keepe your Syring straight, and your Lotium vnspile.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: See, Sir this is she.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: This.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A Curtesan? Now cold bloud defend me, what a proportion afflictes me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O mine aderliuer loue, vat sall me do to requit dis your must affection.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Marry salute my friend, clippe his necke, and kisse him welcome.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A mine art, Sir you bin very velcome.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Kisse her man with a more familiar affection, so, come what entertainement, goe to your Lute. Exit Fran.

And how dost approue my somtimes elected? fees none of your ramping Cannibals, that deuoure mans flesh, nor any of your curtian gulfes, that will neuer be satisfied, vntill the best thing a man
has be throwne into them. I lou'd her with my heart, vntill my soule shewed me the imperfection of my body, and placed my affection on a lawful loue, my modest Beatrice, which if this short heeles knew, there were no being for mee with eyes before her face. But faith, dost thou not some what excuse my sometimes incontinency with her enforciue beauties. Speake.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Hah, she is a whore, is she not?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Whore? fie whore? you may call her a Curtezan, a Cocatrice, or (as that worthy spirite of an eternall happinesse saide) a Suppositarie, but whore? fie: tis not in fashion to call thinges by their right names, is a great marchant, a cockold, you must say, he is one of the liuery, is a great Lord, a foole, you must say he is weake, is a gallant pocky, you must say, he has the court skab, come shees your mistresse or so: Enter Francischina with her Lute .Come Syren your voice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vill not you stay in mine bosome to night loue?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: By no meanes sweet breast, this Gentleman has vowde to see me chastly layde.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He shall haue a bedde too, if dat it please him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Peace you tender him offence, hee is one of a professed abstinence, Syren your voyce and away.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: I loue to sleepe gainst prickle.

sp.p: Thankes, Busse, so the night growes old good rest.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Rest to mine deare loue, rest, and no long absence.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Beleeue me not long.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sall Ick not beleeue you long. Exit Fracischina.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: O yes, come viah, away, boy, on. Exit his Page lighting him

div.stage: Enter Freuill and seemes to ouerheare Malheureus.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is she vnchast, can such a one be damde?
O loue and beautie, yee two eldest seedes
Of the vast Chaos, what strong right you haue,
Euen in thinges diuine, our very soules.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Wha, ha, ho, come bird come, stand peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Are strumpets then such things, so delicate,
Can custome spoile, what nature made so good.
Or is their Custome bad? Beauti's for vse,
I neuer saw a sweet face vitious,
It might be proud, inconstant, wanton, nice,
But neuer tainted with vnnaturall vice.
Their worst is, their best art is loue to winne,
O that to loue should be or shame, or sinne;

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: By the Lord hee's caught, Laughter eternall?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: Soule I must loue her desteny is weake to my affection.
A common loue, blush not faint breast
That which is euer loued of most is best
Let colder-eld the strongst obiections moue,
No lou's without some lust, no life without some loue.

sp.speaker: Eree:
sp.p: Nay come on good sir, what though the most odious spectacle the world can present be an imoÌdest vulgar woman: Yet sir for my sake.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Well sir for your sake Ile thinke better of them.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Doe good sir and pardon me that haue brought you in You knowe the sight of vice augments the hate of sinne.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Hah? will you go home sir 'tis hye bed time.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: With all my hart sir only do not chide me I must confesse.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: A wanton louer you haue been.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: O that to loue should be or shame, or sinne.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Say yee?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let colder eld the strongst obiections mooue.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Howe's this?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: No loue's without some lust,
No life without some loue,
sp.p:
go your wayes for an Apostata, I beleue my cast garment must be let out in the seames for you when all is done,
"Of all the fooles that would all man out-thrust,
" He that 'gainst Nature would seeme wise is worst.

div.head: Actus Secundus. Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Freeuile, pages with torches, and gentlemen with musicke.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: The morne is yet but younge: here gentlemen,
This is my Beatrice window, this the chamber
Of my betrothed dearest, whose chaste eyes,
Full of lou'd sweetnesse, and cleare cherefulnes,
Haue gag'd my soule to her in ioyings,
Shredding away all those weake vnder-braunches,
Of base affections, and vnfruitfull heates,
Here bestow your musick to my voyce. Cantat.
Alwaies a vertuous name to my chast loue,

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Lou'd sir the honor of your wish returne to you,
I cannot with a mistres complement
Forced discoursses, or nice art of wit,
Giue entertaine to your deere wished presence,
But safely thus, what harty gratefulnes,
Vnsulleine Silence, vnaffected modesty,
And an vnignorant shamefastnes can expresse,
Receiue as your protested due. Faith my hart,
I am your seruant,
O let not my secure simplicity, breed your mislike,
As one quite voyde of skill,
Tis Grace inough in vs not to be ill,
I can some good, and faith I mean no hurt,
Do not then sweete wrong sober ignorance,
I iudge you all of vertue, and our vowes,
Should kill all feares that base distrust can mooue,
my soule what say you, still you loue?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: Still? my vowe is vp aboue me, & like time
Irrevocable. I am sworne all yours,
No beauty shall vntwine our armes, no face
In my eyes can or shall seeme faire,
And would to God only to me you might
Seeme only faire; let others disesteeme
Your matchles graces: so might I safer seeme,
Enuie I couet not: far, far be all ostent
Vaine boasts of beauties: soft ioyes and the rest,
"He that is wise, pants, on a priuate brest,
So could I liue in desart most vnknowne,
Your selfe to me enough were Populous,
Your eyes shall be my ioyes, my wine that still
Shall drowne my often cares, your onely voyce
Shall cast a slumber on my listning sence,
You with soft lip shall onely ope mine eyes,
And sucke theire lidds a sunder, onely you
Shall make me wish to liue, & not feare death,
So on your cheekes I might yeild latest breath,
O he that thus may liue, and thus shall dye,
May well be enuied of a dietie.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: Deare my lou'd hart be not so passionate, nothing extreame liues long.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: "But not to be extreame, nothing in loue's extreame my loue receiues no meane.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: I giue you fayth, and pre thee since poore foule I am so easy to beleeue thee, make it much more pitty to deceiue me, weare this sleight fauor in my remembrance. throweth downe a ring to him.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Which when I part from, hope the best of life, euer part from me.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: I take you and your word, which may euer liue your seruant, see day is quite broke vp, the best of houres.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Good morrow gracefull mistres, our nuptiall day holds.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: With happy constancy a wished day. Exit.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: My selfe and all content rest with you.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: The studious morne with paler cheeke drawes on,
The dayes bold light, harke how the free-borne birdes
Caroll their vnaffected passions, The Nitingalls sing.
Now sing they sonnets, thus they crye, we loue
O breath of heauen! thus they harmles soules
Giue intertaine to mutuall affects.
They haue no Baudes: no mercenary bedds
No politike restraints: no artificiall heats
No faint dissemblings, no custome makes them blush,
No shame afflicts theire name, O you happy beastes
In whome an inborne heat is not held sinne,
How far transcend you wretched, wretched man
Whome nationall custome, Tyrannous respects
Of slauish order, fetters: lames his power
Calling that sinne in vs, which in all things els
Is natures highest vertue. (O miseri quorum gaud a crimen haben:
Sure nature against vertue crosse doth fall
Or vertues selfe is oft vnnaturall,
That I should loue a strumpet I a man of Snowe
Now shame forsake me whether am I fallen!
A creature of a publique vse, my frendes loue to
To liue to be a talke to men, a shame
To my professed vertue. "O accursed reason,
" How many eyes hast thou to see thy shameâª
"And yet how blind once to preuent defame?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Diaboli vertus in Lumbis est, morrow my frend; come, I could make a tedious scene of this now but, what, pab, thou art in loue with a Courtezan, why sir, should we loath all strumpet asume men should hate their owne mothers or sisters, a sinne against kinde I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: May it beseeme wise man to be in loue?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Let wise men alone, twill beseeme thee and me well enough.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Shall I not offend the vowe band of our frendship?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: What to affect that which friend affected by heauen I resigne her freely, the creature and I most growe of, by this time shee has assurely heard of my resolued marriage, and no question sweares, Gods Sacrament, ten Towsand Diuells Ile resigne I faith.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: I would but imbrace her, heare her speake, and at the most but kisse her.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: O frend he that could liue with the smoake of roast meate might liue at a cheape rate.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: I shall neere prooue hartely receiued,
A kinde of flat vngratious modesty,
An insufficient dulnes staines my hauiour.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No matter sir, In-sufficiency and sottishnes are much commendable in a most discommendable action, now could I swallow thee, thou hadst wont to be so harsh and cold ile tell thee. Hell and the prodegies of angrie loue are not so fearefull to a thinking minde as a man without affection, why frend, Philosophie & a nature are all one, loue, is the center in which all lines close the common bonde of being.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: O but a chast reserued priuatnes, a modest continence,

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: He tell thee what, take this as firmest sence,
"In Continence will force a Continence,
" Heate wasteth heate, light defaceth light,
"Nothing is spoyled but by his proper might,
This is some thing too waighty for thy floore.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But how so ere you shade it, the worlds eye
Shines not and open out,
Lying, malice, enuie, are held but fidyngs.
Errors of rage, when custome and the world
Calls lust a crime spotted with blackest terrore..

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Where errors are held Crimes, Crimes are but errors
Along sir to her shee is an arrand strumpet: & a strumpet is.
A Sarpego: Venom de Gonory to man. (Offer to go out & suddenly draws back.
Things actually possessed: yet since thou art in loue
And againe as good make vse of a Statue,
A body without a soule, a carkasse three monethes dead,
Yet since thou art in loue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Death man, my destiny I cannot choose.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Nay I hope so, againe they fell but onely flesh,
No iot affection, so that euen in the enioying,
Absentem marmore amque putes, yet since you needs must loue,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Vnauoidable though folly, worse then madnes.

sp.speaker: Free,
sp.l: Its true, but since you needs most loue, you must know this,
He that must loue, a foole, and he must kisse,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Cocledemoy vt vales Domine.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Ago tibi gratias, my worshipfull friend, how do'es your friend?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Out you rascall.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Hang toastes, you are an Asse, much a your worships brayne lyes in your Calues, bread a God boy, I was at supper last night with a new weande bulchin, bread a God drunke, horribly drunke, horribly drunke, there was a wench one Franke Frailty, a puncke, an honest pole-cat, of a cleane In step, found legge, smooth thigh, and the nimble Diuell in her buttocke, all fiest a grace, when saw you Tysefew, or M. Caqueteur, that pratling gallant of a good draught common customes, fortunate, impudence and sound fare.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A way Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cocl,
sp.p: Hang toastes, my fine boy, my companion as worshipfull.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes I heare you are taken vp with schollers and church-men. Enter Holifernes the Barbar.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: QÃ¹anquam to Marce fili my fine boy, does your worship want a Barber Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Farewell knaue, beware the Mulligrubs.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Let the Malligrubs beware the knaue, what a Barbar Surgeon, my delicate boy?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: Yes sir an apprentise to surgery.
Ti, s my fine boy, to what bawdy house doth your Maister belong, whats thy name?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: Holifernes Rain-scure.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Rainscure? good M. Holifernes I desire your further acquaintance, nay pray yee bee couered my fine boy, kill thy itch and heale thy skabes, is thy Maister rotten?

sp.speaker: Holif.
sp.p: My father forsooth is dead.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: And laid in his graue, alas what comfort shall Peggy then haue.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: None but me sir, thats my mothers sonne I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Mothers sonne, a good witty boy, would liue to read an Homilie well, and to whome are you going now?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Marry forsooth to trim M. Mulligrub the Vintner.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Doe you know M. Mulligrub?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: My Godfather Sir.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Good boy hold vp thy chops, I pray thee doe one thing for me, my name is Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: good M. Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Lend me thy bason, razer, and Apron.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: O Lord sir.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Wel spoken, good english, but whats thy furniture worth?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: O Lord sir I know not.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Well spoken, a boy of a good wit, holde this pawne, where dost dwell.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: At the signe of the three razor sir,

sp.speaker: Cocl
sp.p: A signe of good shauing my carastrophonicall fine boy, I haue an odde iest to trim M. Mulligrub for a wager, a iest boy, a humor, Ile returne thy thinges presently, hold.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: What meane you good M. Gudgeon?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Nothing faith but a iest boy, drinke that, Ile recoile presently.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: You'le not stay long.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: As I am an honest man, the 3. razers?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I sir. Exit Holifernes.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p:
Good, and if I shaue not M. Mulligrub, my wit has no edge, and I may goe cacke in my pewter, let me see, a Barbar, my scurule tongue will discouer me, must dissemble, must disguise, for my beard, my false hayre, for my tongue Spanish Dutch, or Welsh, no, a Northerne Barbar, very good, widdow Raine-soures man well, newly entertainde, right, to, hang tostes, all cardes
haue white backes, and all knaues would seeme to haue white breaster, so proceede, now worshipfull Cocledemoy.

div.stage: Exit Cocledemoy in his Barbars furniture.
Enter Marie Eough, and Francischina with her Harye, Loose chafing.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Nay good sweete daughter, doe not swagger so, you heare your loue is to bee married, true, he does cast you off, right he will leaue you to the world, what then? tho blew and white, black and greene leaue you, may not redde and yellow entertain you, is there but one coullor in the Raine-bow?

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: Grand Grincome on your sentences, Gods sacrament, ten towsand diuels take you, you ha brought mine loue, mine honor, mine boddy all to noting.

sp.speaker: Mary Fough.
sp.p: To nothing! I'le be sworne I haue brought them to all the thinges I could, I ha made as much a your maydenhead, and you had beene mine owne daughter, I could not ha sold your Mayden head oftner then I ha done, I ha sworn for you God forgiue me, I haue made you acquainted with the Spaniard Don Skirtoll, with the Italian, M. Beieroane, with the Irish Lord, S. Patrick, with the Dutch Marchant, Haunce Herkin Ginkin Skellam Flappdragon, and specially with the greatest French, and now lastly with this English (yet in my conscience) an honest Gentleman: and am I now growne one of the accursed with you for my labour? is this my reward, am I calde Bawde? Well Mary Fough, goe thy wayes Mary Fough, thy kind heart will bring thee to the Hospitall.

sp.speaker: Francisc.
sp.p: Nay good Naunt, you'le helpe me to an oder loue, vil you not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Out thou naughty belly, wouldst thou make mee thy Bawde? thu'st best make me thy Bawde, I ha kept counsell for thee, who paide the Apothecary, wast not honest Mary Fough? who redeemde thy petticote and mantle, wast not honest Mary Fough? who helped thee to thy custome not of swaggering Ireland Captaines, nor of 2. s. Innes a court men, but with honest atte-cappes, wealthy flat-caps, that pay for their pleasure the best of any men in Europe, nay, which is more in London, and dost thou defile me vile creature.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: Foutra pon you Vitch, Bawde, Pole-catte, Paugh, did not you prayse Freeuill to mine loue?

sp.speaker: Fough.
sp.p: I did prayse I confesse, I did prayse him, I sede hee was a foole, an vnthrift, a true whoremaister, I confesse, a constant drabbe keeper I confesse, but what the winde is turnde.

sp.speaker: Erancis.
sp.p: It is, it is vile woman, reprobate woman, naughtie woman it is, vat sal become of mine poore flesh now, mine boddy must turne Turke for 2. d. O Diuela, life a mine art, Ick sall be reuengde, doe ten thousand Hell damme me, Ick sal haue the rouge trote cut, and his loue, and his friend, and all his affinitie sall smart, sall dye, sal hang, now legion of deuill seaze him, de gran pest, S. Anthonies fire, and de hot Neopolitan poc rotte him.

sp.speaker: Freeuil.
sp.p: Francischina.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O mine feete, deerst, kindest, mine louing, O mine towsand, ten towsand, delicated, petty seet art Cantat Gallice .a mine a deere leeuest affection.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why Monky, no fashion in you? giue entertaine to my friend.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Icke sal make de most of you, dat curtesie may: Aunt Mary, Mettre Faugh, stooles, stooles for des gallantes: mine Mettre sing non oder song, frolique, frolique Sir, but still complaine me doe her wrong, lighten your heart Sir, for me did but kisse her, for me did but kis her, and so let go: Your friend is very heauy, ick sall neere like such sad company.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No thou delightest onely in light Company.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.p: By mine trot, he been very sad, vat ayle you sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A tooth ake Lady, a paultry rheume.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: De diet is very goot for de rheume.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: How far of dwels the house surgeon Mary Fough.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are a prophane fellow I faith, I little thought to heare such vngodly termes come from your lips.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pre de now, tis but a toy, a very trifle.

sp.speaker: Free
sp.p: I care not for the valew, Franke, but I faith-

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
I fait, me must needes haue it (dis is Beatrice ring, oh
could I get it,) seet pree now, as euer you haue embraced me with a hearty arme, a warme thought, or a pleasing touch, as euer you will professe to loue me, as euer you do wish me life, giue me dis ring, dis litle ring.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Pree thee be not vnciuillie importunate, sha not ha't, faith I care not for thee, nor thy ielousie, sha not ha't ifaith.

sp.speaker: Francis:
sp.p: You doe not loue me, I heare of Sir Hubert Subboys daughter Mistresse Beatrice, Gods Sacrament, ick could scratch out her eyes, and sucke the holes.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Goe y'are growne a puncke rampant.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: So get thee gone, nere more behold min eyes by thee made wretched.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Mary Fough farewell, farewell Franck.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Sall I not ha de ring?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: No by the Lord.

sp.speaker: Franck:
sp.p: By te Lord?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: By the Lord.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Goe to your new Blouze, your vnproude sluttery, your modest Mettre forsooth.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Marry will I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Franck:
sp.p: Will you marry forsooth?

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.l: Doe not turne witch before thy time.
With all my hart Sir, you will stay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I am no whit my selfe, Video meliora proboque,
But raging lust my fate all strong doth moue:
"The Gods themselues cannot be wise and loue.

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Your wishes to you. Exit Freeuil:

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Beautie entirely choyce:

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.p: Pray yee proue a man of fashion, and neglect the neglected.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Can such a raritie bee neglected, can there be measure or sinne in louing such a creature:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O min poore forsaken hart.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.l: I can not containe, he saw thee not that left thee,
If there be wisedome, reason, honor, grace
Of any foolishly esteemed vertue,
In giuing o're possession of such beautie,
Let me be vitious, so I may be lou'de,
Passion I am thy slaue, sweete it shall be my grace,
That I account thy loue, my onely vertue:
Shall I sweare I am thy most vowed seruant.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mine vowed, go, go, go, I can no more of loue, no, no, no, you bin all vnconstant, O vnfaithfull men, tyrantes, betrayers, de very enioying vs, looseth us, and when you onely ha made vs hatefull, you onely hate vs: O mine forsaken hart.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I must not raue, Scilence and modesty two customarie vertues: will you be my mistresse?

sp.speaker: Franc:
sp.p: Mettres? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Will you lie with me?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Lie with you, O no, you men will out-lie any woman, fait me no more can loue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No matter, let me enioy your bed.

sp.speaker: Franc,
sp.p: O vile man, vat do you tinck on me, doe you take mee to be a beast, a creature that for sence onely will entertaine loue, and not onely for loue, loue? O brutish abhomination!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why then I pray thee loue, and with thy loue enioy me.

sp.speaker: Franc:
sp.p: Giue me reason to affect you, will you sweare you loue me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So seriously, that I protest no office so dangerous, no deede so vnreasonable, no cost so heauie, but I vow to the vtmost tentation of my best being to effect it.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Sall I, or can I trust againe? O foole,
How naturall tis for vs to be abusde!
Sall ick be sure that no satietie,
No inoying, not time shall languish your affection?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: If there be ought in brayne, hart or hand,
Can make you doubtlesse, I am your vowed seruant.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Will you doe one ting for me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Can I doe it?

sp.speaker: Eranc.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but ick doe not loue dis same Freeuill.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Eranc.
sp.p: Nay I do hate him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Eranc.
sp.p: By this kisse I hate him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I loue to feele such othes, sweare againe.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: No, no, did you euer heare of any that loude at the first sight?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A thing most proper.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Now fair, I iudge it all incredible, vntill this houre I saw you pritty fayre eyed yout, would you enioy me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Rather then my breath, euen as my being.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Vel, had ick not made a vow.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What vow?

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: O let me forget it, it makes vs both despaire.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Deare soule what vow?

sp.speaker: Franck:
sp.p: Hah, good morrow gentle Sir, endeuour to forget me, as I must be enforced to forget all men. Sweet mind rest in you.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Stay, let not my desire burst me, O my impatient heate endures no resistance, no protraction, there is no being for me but your suddaine inioying.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: I doe not loue Freeuil.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: But what vow, what vow?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: So long as Freeuil liues, I must not loue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then he.

sp.speaker: Franc:
sp.p: Must.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Die.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I, no there is no such vehemence in your affectes,
Would I were any thing, so he were not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Will you be mine when he is not?

sp.speaker: Franc
sp.p: Will I? deare, deare breast, by this most zealous kisse, but I will not perswade you: but if you hate him that I loath most deadly, yet as you please, i'le perswade noting.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Will you be onely mine.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.p: Vill I? how hard tis for true loue to dissemble, I am onely yours.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Tis as irreuocable as breath, he dyes. Your loue.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: My vow, not vntill hee be dead,
Which that I may be sure not to infringe,
Dis token of his death, sall satisfie,
He has a ring, as deare as the ayre to him,
His new loues gift: tat got and brought to me.
I shall assured your posessed rest.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To kill a man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O done safely, a quarrell suddain pickt,
with an aduantage strike, then bribe, a little coyne,
Al's safe, deare soule, but Ile not set you on,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay hee is gone, the ring, well, come, little more liberall of thy loue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not yet my vow.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: O heauen, there is no hell but loues prolongings, deare farewell.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Farewell, Now does my hart swell high, for my reuenge,
Has birth and forme, first friend shal kill his friend,
He dat suruiues, i'le hang, besides 'de
Chast Beatrice Ile vexe: onely de ring.
Dat got the world sall know the worst of euils.
"Woman corrupted is the worke of deuils. Exit Fran.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To kill my friend! O tis to kill my selfe,
Yet mans but mans excrement, man breeding man,
As he do's wormes or this, to spoile this nothing, he sits.
The body of a man is of the selfe same soule,
As Oxe or horse, no murther to kill these,
As for that onely part, which makes vs man,
Murther wants power to toucht: O wit how vile,
How hellish art thou, when thou affect nature
Gainst sacred faith! thinke more to kill a friend
To gaine a woman, to loose a vertuous selfe,
For appetite and sensual end, whose very hauing,
Looseth all appetite, and giues satietie,
That corporall end, remorse and inward blushinges,
Forcing vs loath the steame of our owne heates,
Whilste friendship closde in vertue being spiritual,
Tastes no such languishinges and moments pleasure,
With much repentance, but like riuers flow,
And further that they runne, they bigger grow,
Lord how was I misgone, how easie ti's to erre,
When passion wil not giue vs leaue to thinke?
"A learn'd that is an honest man may feare.
" And lust, and rage, and malice, and any thing,
"when he is taken vncollected suddenly:
" Ti's sinne of colde blood; mischiefe wills wak'd eyes,
"That is the damned and the truely vice,
" Not he that's passionles but he 'boue passion's wise,
My friend shall know it all. Exit:

div.stage: Enter Maister Mulligrub, and Mistresse Mulligrub, shee with bag of money.

sp.speaker: Mistresse Mul.
sp.p: It is right I assure you, iust fifteene pounds.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Well Cocledemoy tis thou putst me to this charge, but and I catch thee, I'le charge thee with as many irons: well, is the Barbar come, ile be trimd and then to Cheapeside, to buy a faire peece of plate, to furnish the losse, is the Barbar come?

sp.speaker: Mist: Mul:
sp.p: Truth husband, surely heauen is not pleasde with our vocation; we do winke at the sinnes of our people, our wines are Protestantes, and I speake it to my griefe, and to the burthen of my conscience, we frie our fish with salt butter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Goe looke to your busines, mend the matter and skore falfe with a vengeance.
Welcome friend, whose man?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Widdow Raine soures man, and shall please your good worship, my nam'e's Andrew Sharke.

sp.speaker: M. Mul:
sp.p: How do's my God sonne good Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Very well, hee's gone to trim M. Quicquid our Parson, hold vp your head.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: How long haue you beene a Barbar Andrew?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Not long Sir, this two yeare.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: What and a good worke man already, I dare scarse trust my heade to thee.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: O feare not, we ha polde better men then you, we learn the trade very quickly, will your good worship be shauen or cut?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: As you will, what trade didst liue by, before thou turnedst Barbar Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: I was a Pedler in Germany, but my countrimen thriue better by this trade.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Wha's the newes Barbar, thou art sometimes at Court.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Sometimes pole a Page or so sir.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: And what's the newes? how doe all my good Lordes, and all my good Ladies, and all the rest of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: What an arrogant knaue's this, Ile acquaintance yee (tis cash,) say yee sir. hee spieth the bag

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: And what newes? what newes? good Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Marry sir you know the Conduit at Greenewich, and the vnder-holes that spowtes vp water.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Very well, I was washt there one day, and so was my wife, you might haue wrung her smocke ifaith, but what a those holes?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Thus Sir, out of those little holes in the midst of the night crawlde out 24. huge horrible, monstrous, fearefull deuouring.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Blesse vs.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Serpents, which no sooner were beheld, but they turnd to mastives which howlde, those mastiues instantly turnde to Cockes which crowed, those cockes in a moment were changde to Beares which roard, which Beares are at this hower to bee yet scene in Paris Garden, liuing vpon nothing but toasted cheese and greene onions.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: By the Lord and this may be: my wife and I will go see them, this portends something.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Yes worshipfull Fiest, thou'st feele what portendes by and by.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: And what more newes, you shaue the worlde, especially you Barbar Surgeons you know the ground of many thinges, you are cunning priuie searchers, by the mas you skowre all: what more newes?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: They say Sir that 25, coople of Spanish Iennetes are to bee seene hand in hand daunce the olde measures, whilest fixe goodly Flaunders Mares play to them on a noyse of flutes.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: O monstrous! this is a lie a my word, nay and this bee not a lie, I am no foole I warrant, nay make an Asse of mee once?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Shut your eyes close, wincke sure sir, this bal wil make you smart.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I do winke.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Your head will take cold.
sp.stage: Cocledemoy puts on a Coxe combe on Mulligrubs head.
sp.p:
I will put on your good worships night-cap, whilest I shaue you, so, much: hang toastes: faugh: viah: sparrowes must pecke and
Cocledemoy munch.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 25. couple of Spanish Iennets to daunce the olde measures. Andrew, makes my worshippe laugh, ifaith, dost take me for an Asse Andrew, dost know one Cocledemoy in towne, he made mee an Asse last night, but ile asse him, art thou free Andrew, shaue me well, I shall bee one of the common Councell shortly, and then Andrew, why Andrew, Andrew, doest leaue me in the Suddes? Cantat .why Andrew I shall be blinde with winking. Ha Andrew, wife Andrew, what meanes this, wife, my money wife.

sp.speaker: Mistresse Mul.
sp.p: What's the noyse with you? what aile you?

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: Wheres the Barbar?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p: Gone, I saw him depart long sinne, why are not you trimd?

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: Trimd, O wife, I am shau'd, did you take hence the money?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p: I toucht it not as I am Religious.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: O Lord I haue wink faire.

sp.speaker: Holof:
sp.p: I pray Godfather giue me your blessing.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: O Holofernes, O wheres thy mothers Andrew?

sp.speaker: Holof:
sp.p: Blessing Godfather.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: The diuell choake thee, where's Andrew thy mothers man?

sp.speaker: Holof:
sp.p: My mother hath none such forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: My money, 15. l. plague of all Andrewes, who wast trimd me?

sp.speaker: Holof:
sp.p: I know not Godfather, onelie one mette me, as I was comming to you, and borrowed my furniture, as he saide for a iest sake.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: What kinde of fellow?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: A thick elderly stub-bearded fellow.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: Cocledemoy, Cocledemoy, raise all the Wise men in the streete, Ile hang him with mine owne hands O wife, some Rosa Solis.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul
sp.p:
Good husband take comfort in the Lord, Ile play the Diuell, but ile recouer it, haue a good conscience ti's but a
weekes cutting in the Terme.

sp.speaker: M. Mul:
sp.p: O wife, O wife, O Iacke how does thy mother? is there any Fidlers in the house?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p: Yes, M. Creakes noyse.

sp.speaker: M Mul.
sp.p: Bid 'em play, laugh, make merry, cast vp my accountes, for ile go hang my selfe presently, I will not curse, but a poxe on Cocledemoy, he has polde and shaude the, he has trimd me. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus tertius. Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Beatrice, Crispinell, and Nurs Putifer.

sp.speaker: Puti.
sp.p: Nay good child, A loue once more, M. Freeuils Sonnet, a the kisse you gaue him.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.l: Sha'te good Nurse,
Purest lips soft banks of blisses,
Selfe alone, deseruing kisses,
O giue me leaue to &c.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Pish sister Beatrice, pree reade no more, my stomacke alate stands against kissing extreamly.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Why good Crispinella?

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: By the faith, and trust I beare to my face, tis grown one of the most vnsauorie Ceremonies: Boddy, a beautie tis one of the most vnpleasing iniurious customes to Ladyes: any fellow that has but one nose on his face, and standing coller and skirtes also liude with Tastery sarcenet, must salute vs on the lipps as familierly: Soft skins saue yet here was a stubbearded Iohn a stile with a ploydens face saluted me last day, and stroke his bristles through my lippes, I ha spent 10. shillings in pomatum finde to skinne them againe. Marry if a nobleman or a knight with one locke vissit vs though his vncleane goose turnd greene teeth, hathe palsy his nostrells smell worse then a putrified maribone, & his loose beard drops into our bosome, yet wee must kisse him with a cursy, a curse, for my part I had as liue they would break wynd in my lipps.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: Fy Crispinella you speake too broad.

sp.speaker: Crispi:
sp.p:
No lot sister, lets neere be ashamed to speake what we
be not ashamd to thinke, I dare as boldly speake venery, as think venery.

sp.speaker: Beatâª
sp.p: Faith sister ile begone if you speake so broad.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Will you so? now bashfulnes seaz you, we pronounce boldly Robbery, Murder, treason, which deedes must needes be far more lothsome then an act which is so naturall, iust and necessary, as that of procreation, you shall haue an hipocriticall vestall virgin speake, that with close teeth publikely, which she will receiue with open mouth priuately, for my owne part I consider nature without apparell, without disguising of custome or complement, I giue thoughts wordes, and wordes truth, and truth boldnes, she whose honest freenes makes it her vertue, to speake what she thinks, will make it her necessity to thinke what is good, I loue no prohibited things, and yet I would haue nothing prohibited by policy but by vertue, for as in the fashion of time, those bookes that are cald in, are most in sale and request; so in nature those actions that are most prohibited, are most desired.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: Good quick-sister, stay your pace we are priuat, but the world would censure you, for truly seuere modesty is womens vertue.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Fye, Fye, vertue is a free pleasant buxom qualitie: I loue a constant countenance well, but this froward ignorant coynes, fower austere lumpish vnciuill priuatenes, that promises nothing but rough skins, and hard stooles, ha, fy out good for nothing but for nothing, well nurse, and what do you conceaue of all this?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Nay faith my conceauing dayes be done, marry for kissing ile defend that, thats within my compas, but for my own part heers mistres Beatrice is to be married with the grace of God, a fine gentleman he is shall haue her and I warrant a stronge, he has a legg like a post, a nose like a Lion, a brow like a Bull, and a beard of most faire expectation: this weeke you must marry him, and I now will read a lecture to you both, how you shall behaue your selues to your husbands, the first monneth of your nuptiall, I ha broake my skull about it, I can tell you and there is much braine in it.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Read it to my sister good nurse, for I assure you ile nere marry.

sp.speaker: Put:
sp.p: Marry God forfend, what will you doe then?

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Fayth striue against the flesh, marry? no fayth, husbands are like lotts in the lottery: you may drawe forty blankes before you finde one that has any prise in him, A husband generally is a careles dominering thing that growes like coroll which as long as it is vnder water is soft and tender, but as soone as it has got his branch aboue the waues is presently hard stiffe, not to be bowed but burst, so when your husband is a sutor & vnder your choyse, Lord how suple hee is, how obsequious, how at your seruice sweet Lady: once married got vp his head aboue A stiffe crooked knobby inflexible tyrannous creature he grows then they turne like water, more you would imbrace the lesse you hould, ile liue my owne woman, and if the worst come to the worst, I had rather prooue a wagge then a foole.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: O but a vertuous marriage.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Vertuous marrige? there is no more affinity betwixt vertue and marriage, then betwixt a man and his horse, indeed vertue gerts vp vppon marriage sometimes, and manageth it in the right way, but marriage is of another peece, for as a horse may be without a man, and a man without a horse, so marriage you know is often without vertue, and vertue I am sure more oft without marriage, but thy match sister, by my troth I thinke twill do well, hees a well shapt cleane lipp'd gentleman of a handsome, but not affected finenes, a good faithfull eye, and a well humord cheeke, would he did not stoope in the shoulders for thy sake, see here he is. (Enter Freeuill & Tissefew.)

sp.speaker: Free:
sp.p: Good day Sweete.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Good morrow brother nay you shall haue my lip, good morrow seruant.

sp.speaker: Tisse:
sp.p: Good morrow sweete life.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Life? dost call thy mistres life.

sp.speaker: Tisse
sp.p: Life, yes why not life?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: How many mistresses hast thou?

sp.speaker: Tisse:
sp.p: Some nine.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why then thou hast nine liues like a Cat.

sp.speaker: Tisse.
sp.p: Mew you would be taken vp for that.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Nay good let me still sit, we lowe statures loue still to sit, least when we stand we may be supposed to sit.

sp.speaker: Tisse:
sp.p: Dost not weare high corke shooes: chopines.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Monstrous on's. I am as many other are, peec'd aboue and peec'd beneath.

sp.speaker: Tisse:
sp.p: Still the best part in the,

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: And yet all will scarce make me so high as one of the Gyants stilts that stalkes before my Lord Maiors pageant.

sp.speaker: Tisse:
sp.p: By the Lord so I thought 'twas for some thing Mistres Ioyce iested at thy high insteps.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: She might well inough, and long inough, before I would be ashamed of my shortnes, what I made or can mend my selfe I may blush at; but what nature put vpon me, let her be ashamed for me, I ha nothing to doe with it, I forget my beauty.

sp.speaker: Tisse:
sp.p: Fayth Ioyce is a foolish bitter creature.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: A pretty mildewed wench she is.

sp.speaker: Tisse:
sp.p: And faire.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: As my selfe.

sp.speaker: Tisse:
sp.p: O you forget your beauty now.

sp.speaker: Crisp,
sp.p: Troth I neuer remember my beauty, but as some men doe religion for controuersies sake,

sp.speaker: Beat
sp.p: A motion sister.

sp.speaker: Crisp,
sp.p: Niniuie, Iulius Ceasar, Ionas, or the distruction of Ierusalem.

sp.speaker: Beat,
sp.p: My loue heere.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Pree thee call him not love, 'tis the drabs phrase, nor sweete honie, nor my cunny, nor deare duckling, 'tis the Cittizen termes, but call me him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Anithing, what'st the motion?

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: You know this night our parents haue intended solemnly to contract vs, and my Loue to grace the feast hath promised a maske.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You'le make one Tysefue, and Caqueture shall fill vp a rome.

sp.speaker: Tisse
sp.p: Fore heauen well remembred he borrowed a diamond of me last night to grace his finger in your visitation: The Lying Creature will sweare some straung thing on it now.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Peace, he's here, stand close, lurke.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Good morrow most deere, and worthy to be most wise, how do's my mistresse?

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Morrow sweete seruant, you glister, pree let's see that stone.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: A toy Lady, I bought to please my finger.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why I am more pretious to you, than your finger:

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Yes, or than all my body, I sweare.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why, then let it be bought to please me, come I am no professed beggar.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Troth Mistresse; Zoones: Forsooth, I protest.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Nay, if you turne Protestant for such a toy.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: In good deed la, another time ile giue you a

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Is this yours to giue.

sp.speaker: Caque:
sp.p: O God, forsooth mine, quoth you, nay as for that.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Now I remember, I ha seene this on my seruant Tissefeus finger.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Such another.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Nay, I am sure this is it.

sp.speaker: Caqu:
sp.p: Troth tis forsooth, the poore fellow wanted money to pay for supper last night, and so pawnd it to mee, tis a pawne faith, or else you should haue it.

sp.speaker: Tise:
sp.p: Harke ye, Thou base lying: how dares thy impudence hope to prosper, wer't not for the priuiledge of this respected companie, I would so hange thee.

sp.speaker: Crisp:
sp.p: Come hether seruant, What's the matter betwixt you two?

sp.speaker: Caquââª
sp.p: Nothing but (hearke you) he did me some vnciuile discourtesies last night, for which, because I should not call him to account, hee desires to make me any satisfaction: the Coward trembles at my verie presence, but I ha him on the hippe, ile take the forfeit on his Ringe.

sp.speaker: Tise:
sp.p: What's that you whisper to her?

sp.speaker: Caqu
sp.p: Nothing Sir, but satisfie her, that the Ringe was not pawnd, but onely lent by you to grace my finger, and so tould her I crau'd your pardon, for being too familiar, or indeed ouerbould with your reputation.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Yes indeede he did, he said you desired to make him any satisfaction for an vnciuill discourtesie you did him last night, but he said he had you a the hyp and would take the forfeit of your ring.

sp.speaker: Tise.
sp.p: How now ye base Pultrone?

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my mistresse speakes by contraries.

sp.speaker: Tise.
sp.p: Contraries.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: She iests, faith onely iests.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Sir, Ile no more a your seruice, you are a childe, Ile giue you to my nurse.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: And he come to me, I can tell you as olde as I am, what to doe with him.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: I offer my seruice forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tise.
sp.p: Why so, now euery dogge has his bone to knawe on.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Maske holds, Master Caqueteur.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.p: I am ready Sir, Mistresse Ile daunce with you, neare feare, Ile grace you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I tell you I can my singles and my doubles and my tricke a xxtie, my carantapace, my trauerse forward, and my falling backe yet ifaith.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Mine, the prouision for the night is ours.
Much must be our care, till night we leaue you,
I am your seruant be not tirannous,
Your vertue wan me, faith my loues not lust,
Good wrong me not, my most fault is much trust.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Vntill night onely my heart be with you. Farewell sister.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Adieu brother, come on sister for these sweete meates.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Lets meete and practise presently.

sp.speaker: Tise.
sp.p: Content, weele but fit our pumpes, Come ye pernitious vermine. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: My friend, wished houres, what newes from Babilon? How dos the woman of Sinne, and naturall concupisence?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The eldest child of nature nere beheld So dam'd a creature.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What, In noua fert animus mutatas dicere formas? which way beares the Tyde?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Deare loued Sir, I finde a minde courageously vitious, may put on a desperate securitie, but can neuer bee blessed with a firme inioying and selfe satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: what passion is this, my deare Lindabridis.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Tis well, we both may iest, I ha beene tempted to your death.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What is the rampant Cocatrice growne mad for the losse of hir men?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Deuilishly mad.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: As most assured of my second loue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: She would haue had this ring.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I, and this heart, and in true proofe you were slaine I should bring her this ring, from which she was assured
You would not part, vntill from life you parted.
For which deede, and onely for which deede, I should possesse her sweetnesse.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: O bloody villaines, nothing is defamed but by his proper selfe, Phisitions abuse remedies, Lawyers spoyle the Lawe, and women onely shame women, you ha vow'd my death?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My lust, not I, before my reason would, yet I must vse lust, that I a man of sence should conceiue endelesse pleasure in a body whose soule I know to be so hideously blacke.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That a man at twentie three should cry, O sweete pleasure, and at fortie three should sigh, O sharpe Poxe: but consider man furnished with omnipotencie and you ouerthrowe him, thou must coole thy impatient appetite.
Ti's Fate, ti's Fate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I doe malign my creation that I am subiect to passion, I must inioy her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I haue it marke, I giue a maske to night
To my loues kindred, in that thou shalt goe:
In that we two make shew of falling out,
Giue seeming challenge, instantly depart,
With some suspition to present fight.
We will be seene as going to our swordes,
And after meeting, this Ring onely lent,
Ile lurke in some obscure place, till rumor
(The common Bawde to loose suspitions)
Haue fayned me slaine, which (in respect my selfe
Will not bee found, and our late seeming quarrell)
Will quickly sound to all as earnest truth:
Then to thy wench, protest me surely dead.
Shew her this Ring, inioy her, and bloud colde
Weele laugh at folly.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: O but thinke of it.

sp.speaker: Fre:
sp.p: Thinke of it, come away, vertue let sleepe thy passions, "What old times held as crimes, are now but fashions. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Master Garnish, and Lionell: Master Mulligrubbe, with a standing cup in his hand, and an Obligation in the other, Cocledemoy stands at the other dore disguised like a French Pedler, and ouer-heares them.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: I am not at this time furnished, but ther's my bond for your Plate.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: Your bill had ben sufficient y'are a good man, a standing cup parcell guilt, of 32. ounces. 11. pound, 7. shillings, the first of Iuly, good plate, good man, good day good all.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Tis my hard fortune, I will hang the knaue, no, first he shall halfe rot in fetters in the Dungeon, his conscience made despairfull, ile hyre a Knaue a purpose, shal assure him he is damn'd, and after see him with mine owne eyes, hanged without singing any Psalme. Lord that hee has but one necke.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: You are too tyrannous, you'le vse me no further.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: No Sir, lend mee your seruant, onely to carry the plate home, I haue occasion of an houres absence.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: With easie consent, sir hast and be carefull, Exit Gar.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Be very carefull I pray thee to my wifes owne hands.

sp.speaker: Lion:
sp.p: Secure your selfe sir.

sp.speaker: Mull:
sp.p: To her owne hand.

sp.speaker: Lion:
sp.p: Feare not, I haue deliuered greater thinges than this, to a womans owne hand.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p:
Mounsier, please you to buy a fine delicate ball, sweet
ball; a Camphyer ball.

sp.speaker: Mu:
sp.p: Pre thee away.

sp.speaker: Co:
sp.p: One a ball to skower, a skowring ball, a ball to be shaued

sp.speaker: Mull:
sp.p: For the loue of god talke not of shauing, I haue been shaued, mischeife and 1000. diuells cease him, I haue been shaued. Exit Mullig:

sp.speaker: Co:
sp.p: The Fox growes fat when he is cursed, ile shaue ye smother yet, turd on a tile stone, my lips haue a kind of rhewme at this bole, Ile hau't, Ile gargalize my throate with this Vintner, and when I haue don with him, spit him out, Ile shark, conscience does not repine, were I to bite an honest gentleman a poore grogaran poet, or a penurious Parson, that had but ten pigs tayles in a twelue month & for want of lerning had but one good stoole in a fortnight, I were damd beyond the workes of superarrogation, but to wring the whythers of my gowtie barmd spiggod frigging-iumbler of elements. Mulligrub, I hold it as lawfull as sheepe-shearing, taking egges from hens, caudels from Asses, or butterd shrimps from horses, they make no vse of them, were not prouided for them. And therefore worshipfull Cocledemoy, hang toasts, on, in grace and vertue to proceed, onely beware beware degrees, there be rounds in a ladder, and knots in a halter, ware carts, hang toasts, the comon counsell has decreed it, I must drawe a lot for the great Goblet. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mistresse Mulligrub, and Lionell with a Goblet.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p:
Nay, I pray you stay and drinke, and how do's your Mistresse, I know her verie well, I haue ben inward with her, and so has many more, she was euer a good patient creature yfaith, with all my hart ile remember your master an honest man, he knew me before I was maryed, an honest man hee is, and a crafty, hee comes forward in the world well, I warrant him, and his wife is a proper woman that she is, well, she has ben as proper a woman as any in Cheape, she paints now, and yet she keeps her husbands old Customers to him still. Introth a fine fac'd wife, in a wainscot carued seat, is a worthy ornament to a Tradesman shop, and an atractiue I warrant, her husband shall finde it in the custome of his ware, Ile assure him, God bee with you good youth, I acknowledge the receit. Exit Lion .I acknowledge all the recent sure, tis very well spoken, I acknowledge the receit, thus tis to
haue good education and to bee brought vp in a Tauerne, I doe keepe as gallant and as good companie, though I say it, as any she in London, Squiers, Gentlemen, and Knightes diet at my table, and I doe lend some of them money, and full many fine men goe vpon my score, as simple as I stand heere, and I trust them and truely they verie knightly and courtly promise faire, giue me verie good words, and a peece of flesh when time of yere serues, nay, though my husband be a Citizen and's caps made of wooll, yet I ha wit, and can see my good assoone as another, for I haue all the thankes, my silly husband, a lasse, hee knowes nothing of it, tis I that beare, tis I that must beare a braine for all.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Faire hower to you Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mu:
sp.p: Faire hower, fine terme, faith ile score it vp anone a beautifull thought to you sir.

sp.speaker: Cocl:
sp.p: Your Husband, and my Maister Mr. Garnish has sent you a Iole of fresh Salmon, and they both will come to dinner to season your new cup with the best wine, which cup your husband intreats you to send backe by mee, that his armes may bee grau'd a the side, which he forgot before it was sent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mul
sp.p: By what token, are you sent by no token? nay, I haue wit.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: He sent me by the same token, that he was dry shaued this morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mu.
sp.p: A sad token, but true, here sir, I pray you commend me to your Master, but especially to your Mistresse, tell them they shall be most sincerely welcome. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Shall be most sincerely welcome, worshipfull Cocledemoy, lurke close, hang toasts, be not ashamed of thy qualitie, euerie mans turd smels well in's owne nose, vanish Foyst. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Mulligrub, with seruants and furniture for the Table.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p:
Come spread these Table Diaper Napkins, and doe you heare, perfume this Parlour do's so smell of prophane Tabacco, I could neuer endure this vngodly Tabacco, since one of our Elders, assured me vpon his knowledge Tabacco was not vsed in the Congregation of the family of loue: spread, spread handsomely, Lord these boyes doe things arsie, varsie, you shew your bringing vp, I was a Gentlewoman by my sisters side, I can
tell yee so methodically: methodically, I wonder where it goe that word O sir Amina dub Ruth had me kisse him methodically, I had it somewhere, and I had it indeede.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Mind, be not desperate, ile recouer all All thinges with me, shall seeme honest, that can be profitable, He must nere winch, that would or thriue, or saue, To be cald Nigard, cuckold, Cut-throat, Knaue.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Are they come husband?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Who? what, how now? what feast towards in my priuate Parlour.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Pray leaue your foolerie, what are they come?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Come, who come?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: You need not mak't so strange?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Strange?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: I strange, you know no man that sent me word, that he and his wife would come to dinner to me, and sent this Iole of fresh Salmon before hand.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Peace, not I, peace, the Messenger hath mistaken the house, let's eat it vp quickly, before it be enquir'd for sit to it, som vinegar, quicke, some good luck yet faith, I neuer tasted salmon relisht better, oh when a man feeds at other mens cost.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Other mens cost? why did not you send this Iole of Salmon.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: By Master Garnish man?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Sending me word, that he and his wife would come to dinner to me.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: To season my now bowle?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Bowle?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: And withall wild me to send the bowle backe:

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Backe?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: That you might haue your Armes grau'd on the side?

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: By the same token you were drie shauen this morning before you went forth.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Pah, how this Sammon stinkes.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: And thereupon sent the bowle backe, prepar'd dinner, nay and I bare not a braine.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Wife, doe not vexe, me, is the bowle gone, is it deliuer'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: Deliuered! yes sure, tis deliuered.

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: I will neuer more say my prayers, doe not make mee madde, tis common, let me not crie like a woman, is it gone?

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: Gone? Good is my witnesse, I deliuered it with no more intention to be cozend on't, than the child new borne: and yet

sp.speaker: Mul:
sp.p: Looke to my house, I am haunted with euill spirites, here mee, doe; heare me, if I haue not my Goblet againe, heauen, I'le to the Diuell, I'le to a Coniurer, looke to my house, I'le raise all the wise men ithe streete.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Deliuer vs! what wordes are these, I trust in God, hee is but drunke sure.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: I must haue the Sammon to worship, Cocledemoy, now for the Master peece, God blesse thy necke peece, and Fowtra. Faire Mistresse my Master.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Haue I caught you, what Roger?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Peace good Mistres, I'le tell you all, a lest, a verie mere lest, your husband onely tooke sport to fright you, the bowl's at my Masters, and there is your husband, who sent me in all hast, least you should be ouer frighted with his fayning, to come to dinner to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Praise Heauen, it is no worse.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: And desired me, to desire you to send the lose of Sammon before, and your selfe to come after to them, my Mistresse would bee right glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I pray carry it: now thanke them entierly: blesse me, I was neuer so out of my skinne in my life, pray thanke your Mistresse most entirely.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: So now Figo worshipfull Mall Pough, and I will monch Cheaters & Bawds go together like washing & wringing. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs:
sp.p: Beshrew his heart for his labor, how euery thing about about me quiuers, what Christian my hat and aporne, here take my sleeues, and how I tremose, so Ile gossope it now for't, that's certaine, here has been reuolutions, and false hers indeed.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Whether now? Whats the matter with you now? whether are you a gadding?

sp.speaker: Mestris.
sp.p: Come, come, play the foole no more: Will you goe?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Whether, in the ranke name of madnesse: whether?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Whether, why to mayster Garnish, to eate the Iowle of Salmon? Lord, how strange you make it?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Why so, why so.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Why for why did not you send the selfe same fellow for the Iole of Salmon, that had the cup?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Tis well, tis very well.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: And will me to come and eate it with you at the Goldsmithes.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: OI, I, I, art in thy right wits?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Doe you heare, make a foole of some body else, and you make an asse of me, Ile make an Oxe of you, do ye see.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Nay wife be patient, for looke you, I may be madde, or drunke, or so, for my wise part, though you can bear more then I, yet I can do well: I will not cause nor cary, but heauen knows what I thinke. Come, lets goe neare some musicke, I will neuer more say my praiers. Lets goe heare some dolefull musicke. Nay if Heauen forget to prosper knaves. Ile goe no more to the Synagogue. Now I am discontented, Ile turne Sectarie that is fashion.

div.head: Actus Quartus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Sir Hubert Subboyse, Sir Lyonell Frevile, Crispinella, seruants with lightes.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: More lights: welcome Sir Lyonell Frevile, brother Frevile shortly. Looke to your lights.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.p: The Maskers are at hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Call downe our daughter: Harke they are at hande, ranke handsomly.

div.stage: Enter the Masquers, they daunce. Enter Maheureus and take Beatrice from Frevile. They draw.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Know sir, I haue the aduantage of the place.
You are not safe, I would deale euen with you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So. They exchange gloues as pledges.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I doe beseech you sweet, do not for me prouoke your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: What sodaine flaw is risen?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: From whence come this?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: An vlcer long time lurking, now is burst.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Good sir the time and your deseigns are soft.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I deare sir, councell him, aduise him, twill rellish well From your caruing: Good my sweetnest safe.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: As well, als well, this shall be ended straight.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: The banquet staies, there weele discourse more large,

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Marriage must not make men Cowards.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Nor rage fooles.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: "Tis valor not where heat, but reason rules. Exit,

sp.speaker: Tis.
sp.p: But do you heare Lady, you proud ape you. What was the lest you brake of me euen now?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Nothing, I onely saide you were all mettle, that you had a brazen face, a Leaden braine, and a copper head.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Quicksiluer, thou little more then a Dwarfe, and something lesse then a Woman.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: A Wispe, a wispe, a wispe, will you go to the banquet.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: By the Lord I thinke thou wilt marry shortly too, thou growest somewhat foolish already.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: O I faith, tis a faire thing to be married, and a necessary, To hear this word must, if our husbands be proud, we must bear his contempt, if noysome we must beare with the Gote vnder his armeholes, if a foole we must beare his bable, and which is worse, If a loose liuer, Wee must liue vppon vnholsome Reuersions: Where, on the contrary side, our husbands because they may and we must; care not for vs, thinges hop'd with feare, and got with struglings, are mens high pleasures, when duety pales and flatres their appetite.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: What a tart Monkey is this, by heauen if thou hadst not so much wit I could finde in my hart to my marry thee. Faith bear with me for all this.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Beare with thee, I wonder how thy mother could beare thee ten months in her bellie, when I cannot indure thee 2. hours in mine eie.

sp.speaker: Tis.
sp.p: Alasse for you sweet soule, by the Lorde you are growne a proud, scuruie, apish, ydle, disdainefull, scoffing, Gods foot, because you haue read Ephues and his England, Palmerin de Oliva, & the Legend of Lies.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why yfaith yet seruant, you of all others shoulde beare with my knowne vnmalicious humors, I haue alwaies in my Hart giuen you your due respect:
And heauen may be sworne, I haue priuately giuen faire speach of you, and protested.

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.p: Nay looke you, for my owne part, if I haue not as religiously vowd my hart to you, been in drunke to your health, swalowd flap-dragons, eate glasses, drunke vrine, stabd armes, and don all the offices of protested gallantrie for your sake: and yet you tell me I haue a brazen face, a leaden braineâª and a copper bearde, Come yet and it please you.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: No, no, you do not loue me?

sp.speaker: Tis.
sp.p: By() but I do now, and whosoeuer dares say that I do not loue you, nay honor you, and if you would vouchsafe to marrie.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Naie as for that thinke out as you will, but Gods my record, and my sister knowes I haue taken drinke and slept vppont, that if euer I marrie it shall be you, and I will marrie, and yet I hope I do not saie it shall be you neither.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: By heauen I shalbe assoone wearne of health as of your inioyeng: will you cast a smooth cheeke vpon me?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I haue no crumpt shoulders, my back needs no mantle, and yet marriage is honorable: do you thinke ye shall proue a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.p: No, by the Lord, not I?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Why, I thanke you yfaith:
Heigho: I slept on my backe this morning
And dreamt the strangest dreames:
Good Lord, how things will come to passe?
Will you go to the banquet?

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p:
If you will bee mine, you shall be your owne, my pursse,
my bodie, my hart is yours, onlie bee silent in my house, modest at my table, and wanton in my bed, and the Empresse of Europe cannot content, and shall not be contented better.
