sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Can anie kind hart speake more discreetlie affectionatelie: my fathers consent, and as for mine,

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Then thus, and thus, so Hymen should begin, Sometimes a falling out, proues falling in. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Frevile, speaking to some within, Malhereux at the other dore.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: As you respect my vertue, giue me leaue
To satisfie my reason, though not bloud:
So, all runs right, our fained rage hath tane
To fullest life, they are much possest
Of force most, most all quarrell: now my right friend
Resolue me with open brest, free and true hart
Cannot thy vertue hauing space to thinke
and fortifie her weakened powers with reason,
Discourses, Meditations, Discipline.
Diuine eiaculatories, and all those aydes against deuils:
Cannot all these curbe thy lowe appetite
and sensuall furie?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: "There is no God in bloud, no reason in desire:
Shall I but liue? Shall I not be forc't to act
Some deed, whose verie name is hydeous?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then I must enioy Francischina.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You shall: Ile lend this ring, shew it to that faire Deuill, It will resolue me dead, which rumor with my artificiall absence, wil make most firme, enioy her sodainlie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But if report go strong that you are slaine, and that by me. Whereon I may be seizd Where shall I finde your being.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: At maister Shatewes the Iewellers, to whose breast Ile trust our secret purpose.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I rest your selfe, each man hath follies.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But those worst of all,
"Who with a willing eie, do seeing fall.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Tis true, but truth seemes folly in madnesse spectacles, I am not now my selfe, no man: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: "When woman's in the hart, in the soule hell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Now repentance the fooles whip seize thee,
Nay if there be no meanes Ile be thy friend,
But not thy Vices; and with greatest sence
Ile force thee feele thy errors, to the worst
The vildest of dangers thou shalt sinke into,
No Ieweller shall see me, I will lurke
Where none shall know or thinke, close Ile withdraw,
and leaue thee with two friendes: a whore and knaue
But is this vertue in me? No, not pure,
Nothing extreamely best with vs endures,
No vse in simple purities, the elementes
are mixt for vse, Siluer without alay
Is all to eager to be wrought for vse:
Nor precise vertues euer purely good
Holdes vsefull size with temper of weake bloud:
Then let my course be borne, tho: with side-wind,
The end being good, the meanes are well assingd, Exit.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.l: Come catafugo Francke a Franck-hall, who who ho,
Excellent, Ha, heers a plump rump wench, with a breast
Softer then a Courtyers tongue, an old Ladies gums,
Or an old mans mentula, my fine rogue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pan you poultron.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.l: Gooddy fiste, flumpum pum pum, a my fine Wagtaile,
Thou art as false as prostituted and adulcerate
as some translated manuscript Busse sayre whore, busse.

sp.speaker: Fra,
sp.p: Gods sacramant. Pox.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.l: Hadamoy key dost thou frowne medianthou teukey
Nay look heer: Numeron key Siluer blithe for cany
Os cany goblet: Us key ne moy blcgefoy oteeston pox
On you Gosling.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By me fait dis bin verie fine languge, Ick sall bush ye now, ha, be garzon vare had you dat place?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Hedemoy key, get you gon Punck rampant, key common vp-taile.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: O daughter, cozen, neece, seruant, mistresse.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Humpum, plumpum squat, I am gone. Ex. Cocle.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: There is one M. Malliereux at the dore desires to see you: he saies he must not be deuide, for he hath sent you this ring and withall saies tis done.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vat sall me do now, Gods sacramant: tell him two howers hence he sall be most affectionatlie velcome, tell him (vat sal me do) tel him Ick am bin in my bate, and Ick fall perfume my seetes, mak a mine bodie so delicate for his arme Two houres hence.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I shall satisfie him two houres hence well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Now Ick sall reuange, hay, begar me sal tartar de whole generation, mine braine vorke it, Frevile, is dead, Malhareux sall hang, And mine riuall Beatrice, Ick sall make run madde.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Hees gone forsooth to eate a cawdle of Cock-stones, & will returne within this two houres.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Verie vel, giue mons to some fellow to squire me, Ick sal go abroad.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Thers a lustie Bravo beneath, a stranger, but a good stale Rascall: he sweares valiantlie, kicks a Bawd right vertuously, and protestes with an emptie pocket might desperately, Heele squier you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Very velcom, mine san, Ick sall retorne presantly, now sal me be reuange ten tousant deula, der sall be no got in me but passion, no tought but rage, no mercie but bloud, no spirit but Diula in me, Dere sal noting tought good for me, But dat is mischieuous for others. Exit

div.stage: Enter Sir Hubert, Sir Lyonell Beatrice, Crispinella, and Nurce. Tissefeu following.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.l: Did no one see him since? pray God, nay all is well,
A litle heat, what he is but withdrawne? and yet I would to God,
But feare you nothing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Pray God that all be well or would I were not.

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.p: Hees not to be found Sir, anywhere.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: You must not make a heauy face presage an ill euent: I like your Sister well, shees quick and liuely: would she woulde marry faith.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Marry, nay & I would marry: methinks an old mans a quiet thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Ha, masse and so he is.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: You are a Widdower.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Than I am I faith faire Crisp, and I can tell you, would you affect me, I haue it in me yet I faith.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Troth I am in loue, let me see your hand: would you cast your selfe away vpon me willingly?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Will I: I by the

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Woulde you be a Cockould willingly? By my troath us a comely, fine, and handsome sight, for one of my yeeres to marry an old man, truth tis restoratiue what a comfortable thinge it is to thinke of her husband to heare venerable cough a the euerlastings, no feele his rough skinne, his summer handes, and winter legges, his almoste no eies, and assuredly no teeth, and then to thinke what she must dreame of, when she considers others happines and her owne want: tis a worthy and notorious comfortable match.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Pish, pish, will you haue me?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Will you assure me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Fiue hundred pound ioynture.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: That you will die within this fortnight?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: No, by my faith Cris.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Then Crisp. by her faith assures you sheele haue none of you.

div.stage: Enter Frevile disguis'd like a pandor and Francischina.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p:
Beere leaue Gentles and men of night caps, I would I peak,
But that here stands one is able to expresse her owne tale best.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Sir mine speech is to you, you had a sonne matre Frevile.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Had ha, and haue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No point, me am come to assure you dat on mestre Malheureus hath killed him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: O me, wretched, wretched.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Looke to our daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: How art thou informed?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If dat it please you to go vid me, Ick sall bring you where you'l all hear Malheureus vid his owne lips confesse it, and dare ye may apprehend him and reuenge your and mine loues bloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Your loues bloud mistresse, was he your Loue?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He was so sir, let your daughter it do not veep Lady, de yong man dat be slaine did not you for hee still louitt me ten tousant tousant times more deerely.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: O my hart I will loue you the better I cannot hate what he affected? O passion, O my griefe which way will break, thinke and consume?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Deare woes cannot speake.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For looke you Ladie as your ring he gaue me, vidmost bitter iests at your scornd kindnesse.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: He did not ill not to loue me ,but sure hee did not well to mocke me: Gentle mindes will pittie, though they cannot loue yet peace, and my loue sleep with him. Vnlace good nurse, alas, I was not so ambitious of so supreme an happiness, that he should onlie loue me, twas ioy enough for me poore soule that I only might onlie loue him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O but to be abusde, scornde, scoft at, O ten tousand diula by such a one, and vnto such a one.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I thinke you saie not true sister, shall we know one another in the other world?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: What meanes my sister?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I would faine see him againe: O my torture mind, Frevile is more then dead, he is vnkinde.

div.stage: Exit Beat. and Crisp. and Nurse.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Conuey her in, and so sir as you said Set a strong watch.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I sir, and so passe along with this same common woman, you must make it good.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ick sall, or let me pay for his, mine bloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.p: Come then along all, with quiet speed.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: O Fate?

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.p: O sir, be wisely sorrie, but not passionate. Exit:

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I will goe and reueale my selfe: staie: no, no,
Greefe endeures Loue: Heauen to haue such a wife
Is happinesse, to breed pale enuy in the saintes.
Thou worthy Doue-like virgin without gall,
Cannot (that womans euill) Iealousie,
Despight disgrace, nay which is worst, contempt
Once stirre thy faith. O Truth, how few sisters hast thou?
Deere memorie, with what a suffring sweetnesse, quiet modesty,
Yet deepe affection she receiu'd my death,
And then with what a patient, yet oppressed kindnesse
She tooke my leudlie intimated wrongs. O the derest of heauen?
Were there but three such women in the world, two
Might be saued.
Well, I am great with expectation to what deuilish end
This woman of foule soule will driue her plots:
But prouidence all wicked art ore tops.
"and Impudence must know (tho stiffe as Ice,)
" That fortune doth not alway dote on Vice. Exit.

div.stage: Enter sir Hubert, sir Lyonell, Tyssesue, Franch. and three wah Halberds.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Plant a watch there, be verie carefull Sirs, the rest with vs.

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.p: The heauy night growes to her depth of quiet, Tis about mid darkenesse.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mine shambre is hard by, Ick sall bring you to it presantment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Deepe silence. On

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: within Wa, ha, ha, Ex.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
It was his voice, tis he: he suppes with his cupping glasses. Tis late, he must passe this waie: Ile ha him, Ile ha my fine
boy, my worshipfull Cocledemoy, Ile moy him, he shall be hangd in lowsie linnen, Ile hire some sectary to make him an hereticke before he die? And when he is dead Ile pisse on his graue.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Ah my fine puncks, good night, Franke, frailtie, fraile a Fraile-Hall? Bonus noches my vbiquitari.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ware polling and shauing Sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: A Wolfe, a wolfe, a wolfe, Exit. Cocledemoy

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Heer's something yet, a Cloke, a cloke, yet Ile after, he cannot scape the watch, Ile hang him if I haue any mercyâª Ile slice him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Who goes there? come before the Constable.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Bread a God Constable, you are a Watch for the deuil. Honest men are robd vnder your nose, thers a false knaue in the habit of a Vintner, set vpon me, he would haue had my purse, But I tooke me to my heeles: yet he got my Cloke, a plaine stuffe cloke poore, yet twill serue to hang him? Tis my losse, poor man that I am.

div.stage: Enter Mulligrub running with Cocledemoys cloke.

sp.p: Maisters, we must Watch better, ist not strange that knaues, Drunkerds, and theeues, should be a brode, and yet we of the Watch, Scriueners, smithes, and Taylors, neuer stur.
Harke, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: An honest man and a Cittiezen.
Appeare, appeare, what are you?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: A simple Vintner.
A Vintner ha, and simple, draw neerer, nerer: heers the Cloke.
I Maister Vintner we know you, a plaine stuffe cloke: tis it.
Right, come: Oh thou varlet, doest not thou know that the Wicked cannot scape the eies of the Constable?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: What meanes this violence, as I am an honest man I tooke the cloke.
As you are a knaue, you tooke the cloke, we are your witnesses for that.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: But heare me, heare me, Ile tell you what I am.
A theefe you are.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I tell you my name is Mullegrub.
I will grubbe you, In with him to the stockes, there let him sit tell to morrow morning that Iustice Quodlibet may examine him.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Why but I tell thee.
Why but I tel thee, weele tell thee now.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Am I not mad, am I not an asse,
Why scabs, Gods foot: let me out.

sp.p: I, I, let him prate, he shall find matter in vs scabs I warrant: Gods so, what good members of the common wealth, doe wee proue.
Prethee peace, lets remember our duties, and let go sleepe, in the feare of God. Exeunt.

div.stage: Hauing left Mullegrub in the stocks.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Who goes there: I lo, ho, ho: zounds shall I run mad, Loose my wits: shall I be hangd, hark: who goes there? Do not feare to be poore Mullegrub, Thou hast a sure stocke now.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.l: The night growes old,
And many a cockould is now Wha, ha, ha, ho,
Maids on their backes,
Dreame of sweet smackes, and warme: Wo, ho, ho, ho,
I must go comfort my venerable Mullegrub, I must
Fiddle him till he fyst: fough:
Maides in your Night-railes,
Looke well to your light
Keepe close your lockes,
and downe your smocks,
Keepe a brode eie
And a close thigh, excellent, excellent, whos's there?
Now Lord, Lord, (maister Mullegrub) deliuer vs: what does your Worship in the stocks? I pray come out Sir.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Zounds man I tell thee I am lockt.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p:
Lockt: O world: O men: O time: o night: that canst not
Discerne vertue, and wisdome, and one of the common Counsel: What is your Worship in for?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: For (a plague ont) suspition of Fellonie.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Nay, and it be but such a trifle, Lord I could weep, to see your good Worship in this taking: your Worshippe has beene a good friend to me, and tho you haue forgot me, yet I knewe your wife before she was married, and since I haue found your Worsh. dore open and I haue knockt, and God knows what I haue saued: and doe I liue to see your Worship stockt?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Honest Belman, I perceiue thou knowst me, I prethe call the Watch. Informe the Constable of my reputation, That I may no longer abide in this shamefull habitation, And hold thee, all I haue about me.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Tis more then I deserue sir: Let me alone for your Deliuerie.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Doe, and then let me alone with Cockledemoy, Ile moy him.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Maids in your: Maister Constable, whos's that ith' stoks?
One for a robberie: one Mullegrub, he cals himselfe. Mullegrub? Bel-man, knowst thou him?

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Know him: O maister Const. what good seruice haue you done. Know him? Hees a strong theefe, his house has beene suspected for a bawdie Tauerne a great while: and a receipt for Cut-purses, tis most certaine: He has beene long in the blacke booke, and is he tane now?
Berlady my maisters weele not trust the stocks with him, Weele haue him to the Iustices, get a Mittimus to Newgate presentlie. Come sir, come on sir.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ha: does your Rascalship yet know my Worship In the end?
I, the end of your Worship we know.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ha, goodman Constable, heeres an honest fellow can tell you what I am?
Tis true sir, yare a strong theefe hee saies on his owne knowledge: Binde fast, binde fast, we know you: Weele trust no Stocks with you. Awaie with him to the Iayle instantlie.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Why but dost heare Bel-man, Rogue, Rascall, Gods
Whie but? The constable drags awaie mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Whie but; wha ha ha, excellent, excellent, ha my fine Cocledemoy, my Vintner fistes, Ile make him fart crackers before I ha done with him; to morrow is the daie of Iudgment.
Afore the Lord God my knauerie growes vnperegall, Tis time to take a nap, vntill halfe an houre hence: God giue your Worship Musicke, content, and rest.

div.head: Actus Quintus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Franchischina, sir Lyonel, Tissefeu, with Officers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You bin verie velcom to mine shambra.

sp.speaker: sir Lyo.
sp.p: But how knowe ye, how are ye assurde Both of the deed, and of his sute returne.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O Myn-here. Ick sall tell you, metre Malhereux
Came all bretlesse running a my shambra
His sword all bloudie: he tel a me he had kil Frevile,
And pred a me to conceale him:
Ick flatter him, bid bring monies, he should liue and lie vid me,
He went whilst Ick (me hope vidout sins) out of mine
Mush loue to Frevile betraie him.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Feare not, tis well: good works get grace for sin.
sp.stage: She conceales them behinde the curtaine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dere, peace, rest dere, so softlie, all goe in:
De net is laie, now sal Ick be reuenge.
If dat me knew a dog dat Frevile loue,
Me would puisson him, for know de deepest hell
As a reuenging Womans, naught so fell.

sp.speaker: mary.
sp.p: Ho Cosen Francke, the partie you wot of, M. Malhereux.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bid him come vp, I prede.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O min here man, a dere liuer Loue,
Mine ten tousant times velcom Loue,
Ha, by mine trat, you bin de iust, vat sall me saie:
Vat seet honie name sall I call you?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Anie from you is pleasure. Come my louing
Prettinesse, wheres thie Chamber?
I long to touch your sheetes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, no, not yet mine sweetest soft-lipped loue:
You sall not gulp downe all delights at once:
Be min trat, dis all-fles-Louers, dis rauenous Wenches
Dat sallow all downe hole, vill haue all at one bit,
Fie, fie, fie, be min fait dey do eate
Comfets vid spoones.
No, no, Ile make you chew your pleasure vit loue,
"De more degrees and steps, de more delight,
" De more endeered is de pleasure hight.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What your a lerned wanton, and proceed by art?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Go little vag, pleasure should haue a
Cranes long necke, to relish de Ambrosia of
Delight.
And Ick pre de tel me, for me loues to heare of manhood
Verie mush, Isait: Ick prede (vat vas me a saieng)
Oh, Ick prede tell a me:
How did you kill a metre Frevile?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why quareld a set purpose, drew him out, Singled him, and hauing th'advantage of my sword and might, ran him through and through.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vat did you vid him van he was sticken?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I dragd him by the heeles to the next wharffe and spurnd him in the Riuer.

div.stage: Those in ambush rusheth forth and takes him.

sp.speaker: sir Lyo.
sp.p: Seize, seize him: O monsterous? O ruthlesse Villaine?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: What meane you Gentlemen? by heauen,

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Speake not of anie thing thats good.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your errors giues you passion: Frevile liues.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Thie own lips saie, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Let me die if at Shatewes the Ieweller, he liues not safe vntoucht.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Meane time to stricktest guard, to sharpest prison.

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: No rudenesse Gentlemen: Ile go vndragd.
O wicked, wicked Diuell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.l: Sir, the daie of triall is this morn,
Lets prosecute the sharpest rigor, and seuerest end:
"Good men are cruell, when the'are vices friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.l: Woman we thanke thee, with no emptie hand,
Strumpets are fit, fit for som-thing. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I, for Hell: O thou vnrepriueable, beyond all
Measure of Grace dambd immediatlie:
That things of beautie created for sweet vse:
Soft comfort, and as the verie musicke of life,
Custome should make so vnutterablie hellish?
O heauen, what difference is in women, and their life?
What man, but worthie name of Man:
Would leaue the modest pleasures of a lawfull bed:
The holie vnion of two equall harts
Mutuallie holding either deere as health,
The vndoubted yssues, Ioyes of chast sheetes,
The vnfained imbrace of sober Ignorance:
To twine the vnhealthfull loynes of common Loues,
The prostituted impudence of things.
Sencelesse like those by Cataracks of Nyle,
"Their vse so vile, takes awaie sence how vile,
" To loue a creature, made of bloud and hell,
"Whose vse makes weake, whose companie doth shame,
" Whose bed doth begger: yssue doth defame.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Metre Frevile liue: ha, ha, liue at mestre Shatewes:
Mush at metre Shatews. Frevile is dead. Malhereux sall hang,
And swete diuel, dat Beatrice would but run mad, dat
she would but run mad, den me would dance and sing,
Metre Don Dubon, me pre ye now go to Mestres
Beatrice, tel her Frevile is sure ded, and dat he
Cursse hir selfe especiallie, for dat he was
Sticked in hir quarrell, swering in his last gaspe,
Dat if it had bin in mine quarrels,
Twould neuer haue greeued him.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Prede do, and saie anie ting dat vil vex her.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Let me alone to vex her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Vil you, vil you mak a her run mad? here take
Dis ring, sea me scorne to wear anie ting dat washers,
Or his: I prede torment her, Ick cannot loue her,
She honest and vertuous forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Is she so? O vile creature? then let me alone with her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Vat. Vil you mak a her mad? seet by min trat,
Be pretta seruan, Bush, Ick sall go to bet now.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Mischiefe whether wilt thou? O thou tear-lesse woman?
How monstrous is thy Deuill,
The end of Hell as thee.
How miserable were it to be vertuous, if thou couldst prosper?
Ile to my Loue, the faithfull Beatrice,
She has wept enough, and faith deere soule too much.
But yet how sweet it is to thinke
How deere ones life was to his Loue: how moornd his death.
Tis Ioy not to be exprest with breath:
But O let him that would such passion drinke,
Be quiet of his speech, and onlie thinke. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Sister, cannot a woman kill her selfe? Is it not lawfull to die when we should not liue?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: O sister tis a question not for vs, we must do what God will.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What God will? Alasse, can torment be his glorie, or our greefe his pleasure? Does not the Nurces nipple iuic'd ouer with Wormwood, bid the childe it shoulde not sucke? And does not Heauen when it hath made our breath bitter vnto vs, say we shud not liue? O my best sister: to suffer wounds when one may scape this rod, is against nature, that is against God.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Good sister do not make me weep: sure Frevile was not false: Ile gage my life that strumpet out of craft
And some close second end hath malist him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: O sister if he were not false, whom haue I lost?
If he were: what griefe to such vnkindnesse,
From head to foote I am all myserie:
Onely in this, some iustice I haue found
My griefe is like my loue, beyond all bound. Enter Nurse

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: My seruant, maister Cacature desires to visite you,

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: For griefes sake keepe him out, his discourse is like the long word, Honorificabilitudinitatibus: a great deale
Of sound and no sence: his companie is like a parenthesis.
To a discourse you may admit it, or leau it out, it makes no matter.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: By your leaue sweet creatures.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Sir, all I can yet say of you, is, you are vnciuill.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You must denie it: By your sorrowes leaue,
I bring some mussicke, to make sweet your griefe,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What ere you please: O breake my hart
Canst thou yet pant? O dost thou yet seruiue,
Thou didst not loue him, if thou now canst liue:

div.l: O Loue, how strangely sweet
are thy weake Passions,
That loue and ioy should meete
in selfe same fashions.
O who can tell
the cause why this should moue?
But onely this,
no reason, aske of Loue.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Hold, peace, the gentlest soule is sowned, O my best sister.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Ha, get you gone, close the dores: My Beatrice,
Curst be my indiscreet trials: O my immeasureablie louing.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: She stirs, giue aire, she breathes.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Where am I, ha? how haue I slipt off life?
Am I in heauen? O my Lord, though not louing
By our eternall being, yet giue me leaue
To rest by thie dear side: am I not in heauen?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: O eternallie much laued, recollect your spirits.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Ha, you do speake, I do see you, I do liue,
I would not die now: Let me not burst with wonder.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Call vp your bloode, I liue to honor you,
As the admired glorie of your sex.
Nor euer hath my loue bin false to you.
Onely I presum'd to try your faith too much,
For which I most am grieued.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Brother; I must be plaine with you, you haue wrong'd vs.
I am not so Couetous to deny it,
But yet when my discourse hath staide your quaking,
You will be smoother lipt: and the delight
And satisfaction which we all haue got,
Vnder these strange disguisings, when you know,
You will be milde and quiet, forget at last,
"It is much ioy to thinke on sorrowes past.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Do you then liue? and are you not vntrue?
Let me not die with Ioy, pleasure's more extream:
Then greefe, thers nothing sweet to man but meane.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Heauen cannot be too gratious to such goodnesse, I shall discourse to you the seueral chances, but harke I must yet rest disguisd, the sudden close of many drifts now meet,
"Where pleasure hath some profit, art is sweet. Enter Tisefeu.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Newes, newes, newes, newes.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Oysters, Oysters, oysters, oysters.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Why, is not this well now? Is not this better then louring, and pouting, and puling, which is hatefull to the liuing, and vaine to the dead? Come, come, you must liue by the quicke, when all is done, and for my owne part, let my wife laugh at me when I am dead, so sheele smile vpon me whilst I liue, but to see a woman Whine, and yet keepe her eies drye mourne, and yet keepe her cheekes fat: nay, to see a woman claw her husbande by the feete when he is dead, that would haue scratcht him by the face when he was liuing: this now is somewhat rediculous.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Lord how you prate.

sp.speaker: Tis.
sp.p: And yet I was afraide ifaith that I shoulde ha seene a Garland on this beauties herse, but time, truth, experience, and varietie, are great doers with women.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But whats the newes? the newes I pray you?

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: I pray you? nere pray me: for by your leaue you may command me. This tis: the publique sessions which this day is past, hath doom'd to death ill fortun'd Malhereux.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: But sir, we heard he offerd to make good,
That Freuile liu'd at Shatews the Iewellers.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: And that twas but a plot betwixt them two.

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.l: O I, I, he gagd his life with it, but know
When all approcht the test, Shatews deuide
He saw or heard of any such complot,
Or of Freuill: so that his owne defence,
Appeard so false, that like a madmans sword,
He stroke his owne hart, he hath the course of law
and instantly must suffer: but the Iest
(If hanging be a iest) as many make it)
Is to take notice of one Mullegrub, a sharking vintner.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: What of him Sir.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Nothing but hanging, the Whoresone slaue is mad before he hath lost his sences.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Was his fact cleere and made aparant Sir?

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.l: No faith suspitions, for twas thus protested
a cloke was stolne, that cloke he had, he had it
Himselfe confest by force, the rest of his defence
The choller of a Iustice wrongd in wine,
Ioynd with malignance of some hastie Iurors,
Whose wit was lighted by the Iustice nose, The knaue was cast,
But Lord to heare his mone, his praiers, his wishes,
His zeal ill timde, and his words vnpittied,
Would make a dead man rise and smile,
Whilst he obserued how feare can make men vile.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Shall we go meet the execution?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I shall be rulde by you.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.l: By my troth a rare motion, you must hast,
For male-factors goes like the world vpon wheeles.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Will you man vs, you shall be our guide to Freuile.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I am your seruant.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Ha seruant? Zounds I am no companion for Pandors, your best make him your loue.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: So will I Sir, we must liue by the quicke you say.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.l: Sdeath a vertue, what a damnd things this?
Whole trust faire faces, teares, and vowes, Sdeath not I,
She is a woman, that is, she can ly.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Come, come, turne not a man of time, to make al il,
Whose goodnesse you conceiue not, since the worst of chance
Is to craue grace for heedlesse ignorance.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: So, I ha lost my Sergeant in an ecliptique mist, drunke, horrible drunke, he is fine: so now will I fit my selfe, I hope this habit will do me no harme, I am an honest man already: fit, fit, fit as a puncks taile, that serues euery body: By this time my Vintner thinkes of nothing but hel and sulpher, he farts fire and brimstone already, hang tostes, the execution approcheth.

div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonell: Sir Hubert, Malhereux piniond, Tysefeu, Beatrice, Frevile, Crisp. Francischina, and Holberds.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I do not blush, although condemnd by lawes,
No kind of death is shamefull but the cause:
Which I do know is none, and yet my lust
Hath made the one (although not cause) most iust.
May I not be repriued? Freuile is but mislodgd,
Some lethargie hath seazd him, no, much mallice,
Do not lay bloud vpon your soules with good intents,
Men may do ill and law sometime repents.

div.stage: Cockledemoy picks Malhereuxes pocket of his purse.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Sir, sir, prepare, vaine is all lewd defence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: "Conscience was law: but now lawes Conscience,
My endles peace is made, and to the poore,
My purse, my purse.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: I Sir, and it shall please you the poore has your purse already.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You are a Welyman,
But now thou sourse of Deuils, Oh how I lothe
The very memory of that I adorde,
He thats of faire bloud, well meand, of good breeding,
Best fam'd, of sweet acquaintance and true friends,
And would with desperate Impudence loose all these,
And hazard landing at this fatall shore,
Let him nere kill, nor steale, but loue a Whore,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: De man dose raue, tinck a got, tinck a got, and bid de flesh, de world, and the dible farewell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Farewell. Freuile discouers himselfe.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vat ist you sea, ha?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Sir your pardon, with my this defence,
Do not forget protested violence
Of your low affections no requests,
No arguments of reason, no knowne danger.
No assured wicked bloodines,
Could draw your hart from this damnation.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why staie.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vnprosperous Diuell, vat sall me do now.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Therefore to force you from the truer danger,
I wrought the fained, suffering this faire Deuil,
In shaps of woman to make good her plot,
And knowing that the hooke was deeply fast,
I gaue her line at will, till with her owne vaine striuings,
See here shees tired: O thou comely damnation?
Doest think that vice is not to be withstood,
O what is woman meerely made of bloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: You maze vs all, let vs not be lost in darkenesse?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: All shall be lighted, but this time and place
Forbids longer speech, onlie what you can thinke
Has bin extreamlie ill is onelie hers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: To seuerest prison with her, with what hart canst liue? What eies behold a face?

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.l: Ick vil not speake, torture, torture your fill,
For me am worse then hangd, me ha lost my will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: To the extreamest whip and Iaile.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Frolique, how is it Sirs?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I am my selfe, how long wast ere I could
Perswade my passion to grow calme to you?
Rich sence makes good bad language, and a friend
Should waigh no action, but the actions end.
I am now worthie yours, when before
The beast of man, loose bloud distemperd vs,
"He that lust rules cannot be vertuous.

div.stage: Enter Mullegrub mistris Mullegrub and officers.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: On afore there, roome for the prisoners?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I praie you do not lead me to execution through cheapeside, I owe M. Burnish the gold-smith monie, and I feare heele set a Seriant on my backe for it.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Trouble not your skonce my Christian Brothers, but haue an eie vnto the maine chance, I will warrant your shouldiers, as for your necke Plinius secundus, or marcus Tullius Cycero, or somebodie it is saies, that a three foulde corde is hardlie broken.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Wel, I am not the first honest man that hath bin cast away, and I hope shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: O sir, haue a good stomach and mawes, you shal haue a ioyfull supper.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.p: In troth I haue no stomach to it, and it please you take my trencherâª I vse to fast at nights.

sp.speaker: mistris mul.
sp.p: O husband, I little thought you should haue come to think on God thus soon: nay and you had bin hangd deseruedly, it would neuer haue greeud me, I haue known of many honest innocent men haue bin hangd deseruedly, but to be cast away for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Good woman hold your peace, your prittles & your prattles your bibbles and your babbles, for I pray you heare mee in priuate, I am a widdower, and you are almost a widdow, shal I be welcom to your houses, to your tables, and your other things.

sp.speaker: mist mul.
sp.p: I haue a peece of mutton and a featherbed for you at all times, I pray make hast.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I do here make my confession, if I owe anie man anie thing, I do hartilie forgiue him: if any man owe me anie thing, let him paie my wife.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: I will looke to your wiues paiment I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: And now good yoke-fellow leaue thy poor mulligrub.

sp.speaker: mist. mul.
sp.p: Naie then I were vnkind yfaith, I will not leaue you vntill I haue seene you hang.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: But brothers, brothers, you must thinke of your sins and iniquities, you haue bin a brocher of prophane vessels, you haue made vs drinke of the iuice of the whore of Babylon, for whereas good ale, Perrys, Bragets, Syders, and metheglins, was the true auntient British and Troyan drinks, you ha brought in Popish wines, Spanish wines, French wines, tam marti quam mercurio, both muscadine and malmsey, to the subuersion, staggering, and sometimes ouerthrow of manie a good Christian: You ha bin a great Iumbler, O remember the sins of your nights, for your night works ha bin vnsauorie in the tast of your Customers.

sp.speaker: mul.
sp.p: I confesse, I confesse, and I forgiue as I would be forgiuen, Do you know one Cocledemoy?

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: O verie wel: know him? an honest man he is and a comly, an vpright dealer with his neighbours, and their wiues speake good things of him.

sp.speaker: mul.
sp.p: Wel, whersoere he is, or whatsoere he is, Ile take it on my death hees the cause of my hanging, I hartily forgiue him, and if he would come forth he might saue me, for he only knowes the why, and the wherfore.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: You do from your harts, and midrifs, and intrales forgiue him then you wil not let him rot in rusty Irons, procure him to be hangd in lowsie linnen without a song, and after he is dead pisse on his graue.

sp.speaker: mul.
sp.p: That hard hart of mine has procurd all this, but I forgiue as I would be forgiuen.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hang tosts my Worsh.

sp.speaker: mulli.
sp.p: behold thy Cocledemoy, my fine vintner, my castrophomicall fine boy: behold and see.

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.p: Blisse, a the blessed, who would but look for 2. knaues here?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: No knaue wor. friend, no knaue, for obserue honest Cocledemoy restores whatsoeuer he has got, to make you know, that whatsoere he has don, has bin only Euphoniae gratia, for Wits sake: I acquit this Vintner as he has acquitted me, all has bin done for Emphises of wit my fine boie, my worshipfull friends.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Goe you are a flattring knaue.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: I am so, tis a good thriuing trade, it coms forward better then the 7. liberal Sciences, or the nine cardinall vertues, whiche may well appeare in this, you shall neuer haue flattering knaue turn courtyer: and yet I haue read of many Courtyers that haue turned flattring knaues.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Wast euen but so, why then als well?

sp.speaker: mull.
sp.p: I could euen weepe for ioy.

sp.speaker: mist, mul.
sp.p: I could weep to, but God knowes for what.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Hers another tack to be giuen, your son and daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ist possible, hart I, al my hart, wil you be ioyned here?

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: yes faith father, mariage and hanging are spun both in one houre.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p:
Why then my worsh. good friends I bid my selfe most hartily welcome to your merry nuptials, and wanton Iigga-ioggies And now my verie fine Heliconian Gallantes, and you my Worsh. friends in the middle Region:
If with content our hurtlesse mirth hath bin,
Let your pleasd minds as our much care hath bin:
For he shall find that slights such triuiall wit,
Tis easier to reproue then better it:
We scorne to feare, and yet we feare to swell,
We do not hope tis best: tis all, if Well. Exeunt. FINIS. Exeunt

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
